Dear Mr. Culp:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
9/9/2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations,
please address how the previous CAP did or did not adequately address
the issue, and what additional steps will be taken going forward to ensure
compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(c) Training needs of the family.
One of eight foster home files held a reevaluation that did not have an assessment
of the foster parent’s training needs.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One of eight foster home reevaluations was not submitted to the department within
the required timeframe. The reevaluation was submitted on 8/14/20, with an
expiration date of 8/20/20.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Renewal evaluation dated 9/11/18, CAP approved 10/2/18.
Interim evaluation dated 10/14/19; CAP approved 11/7/19
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
4

One of eight foster care files had an overdue initial medical exam. The youth
entered care on 6/24/20; a medical was due by 7/23/20.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Renewal evaluation dated 9/11/18, CAP approved 10/2/18.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every
18 months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
Two of eight foster care files had overdue dental examinations.
One youth last had a dental in December 2018. Therefore, a dental exam was due
by June 2020
Another youth last had a dental in November 2018. Therefore, a dental exam was
due by May 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Interim evaluation dated 10/14/19; CAP approved 11/7/19
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child: (a-j)
One of eight foster care files did not have documentation of the required information
being provided to the foster parent at placement. The DHHS 3307 Placement
Outline was filled out by the worker, but it was not signed by the foster parent, nor
was there any indicator that the foster was provided this information by phone or
email
REPEAT VIOLATION
Renewal evaluation dated 9/11/18, CAP approved 10/2/18.
Interim evaluation dated 10/14/19; CAP approved 11/7/19
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
5

(g) Current documentation of financial support sufficient to
meet the youth's housing, clothing, food, and miscellaneous
expenses.
One of three IL files did not have budgets completed on a monthly basis. Over the
previous 12 months, budgets were only completed in April and August 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Renewal evaluation dated 9/11/18, CAP approved 10/2/18.
Interim evaluation dated 10/14/19; CAP approved 11/7/19
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of three IL files did not have quarterly reviewed IL contracts. The file
documented that the contract was only reviewed in August 2019 and August 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Renewal evaluation dated 9/11/18, CAP approved 10/2/18.
Interim evaluation dated 10/14/19; CAP approved 11/7/19
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3)The agency shall document all of the following in the child’s
record before a change of placement occurs:

REPEAT VIOLATION
Interim evaluation dated 10/14/19; CAP approved 11/7/19
R 400.12403 Policy and procedures
The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of the
following areas: (i)Service plans
6

Three of eleven FC/IL service plans were not approved by the supervisor within 14
days of completion as required by the agency policy FOM 722-09 (page 27).
File one: 7/22/20 USP approved 8/20/20
File two: 7/24/20 USP approved 8/17/20
File three: 11/6/19 USP approved 12/2/19
One of eleven FC/IL service plans did not have documented supervision within 14
days prior to approving the service plan, as required by agency policy.
File one: USP approved 7/10/20, supervision occurred 7/14/20.
R 400.12403 Policy and procedures
The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of the
following areas: (j) visitation
One of eight foster care case files did not have proper visitation documented for a
child who has returned home, as required by the agency policy FOM 722-6H (page
6). The policy requires weekly home visits for the first month after a child returns home,
then home visits twice per month until the case closes.
File one: The child returned home January 2019. Twice monthly visits were not
completed as required. One monthly visit was missing for each of the following
months: October and December 2019, January, March, June, and July 2020. Two
monthly visits were missing for November 2019 and April 2020.
In addition, two of eight foster care case files did not have sibling visits documented
as required by their policy 722-06I and CI 19-090.
File one: No sibling visits were documented for September, October, or November
2019.
File two: No sibling visits were documented for July or August 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Interim evaluation dated 10/14/19; CAP approved 11/7/19
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.30 Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66)
Page 27
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall review and approve each
service plan. The plan can be approved only after the supervisor
7

has a face-to-face meeting with the worker, which can be the
monthly meeting.
Two of eleven FC/IL files did not have supervision between the worker and
supervisor documented monthly/prior to signing a USP.
File one: The 8/31/20 USP did not have supervision documented prior to approval.
File two: Supervision was not documented for September or October 2019, and July
2020.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 801 Medical passport
Page 11-13
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport containing all items listed in MCL
722.954c.
Six of eleven FC/IL case records did not have Medical Passports as required.
File one: Did not have documentation that an IL youth received their Medical
Passport within two weeks of entering YAVFC.
File two: Medical passports were completed on 8/8/19 and 2/20/20, not quarterly as
required. A medical passport was not documented to have been given to the parent
at reunification on 6/20/20.
File three: Medical passports were completed on 5/20/19 and 3/23/20, not quarterly.
File four: A medical passport was not completed in December 2019. The 3/31/20
passport is missing the caregiver signature.
File five: 8/20/20 and 7/20/20 passports are missing youth and provider signature.
No passports were completed prior to July 2020.
File six: No medical passports were on file.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Renewal evaluation dated 9/11/18, CAP approved 10/2/18.
Interim evaluation dated 10/14/19; CAP approved 11/7/19
FOM 722-03B Initial Safety Screen
Page 4
Caseworkers must complete a DHS-588, Initial Relative Safety
Screen, for all adult relatives who express an interest in
placement, within five business days of the relative's written
request for placement consideration.
8

One of eight foster care case files did not have a completed 588 on record prior to
placement with a relative on 7/20/20.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Renewal evaluation dated 9/11/18, CAP approved 10/2/18.
FOM 801 Medicaid Card and Consent
Page 18
Each child in care must be enrolled in Medicaid (MA) and have
an assigned MA recipient ID number to ensure prompt health
services for foster children at the time of placement. The foster
care provider is given the DHS-3762, Consent to Routine, Non-
Surgical Medical Care and Emergency Medical/Surgical
Treatment card, which allows the provider to take the child to
the doctor and respond to emergencies. The DHS-3762 is
completed by the caseworker placing the child and the
caseworker must enter the child’s MA number on the card (if
child is already on MA).
Two of eleven FC/IL youth did not have documentation in their file that their
caregiver was provided with the 3762 at replacement.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Renewal evaluation dated 9/11/18, CAP approved 10/2/18.
FOM 722-06H Timely entry of caseworker contacts
Page 15-16
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within
five business days of the contact.
All other social work contacts must be entered prior to the report
period end date on the applicable case service plan.
Three of eleven FC/IL case files were found to have contacts entered late.
File one: Supervision contact for June 2020, was entered 9/8/20.
File two: 10/4/19 contact entered 10/16/19; 12/17/19 entered 1/2/20; 1/16/20 entered
1/27/20; 2/27/20 entered 4/20/20, 8/6/20 entered 8/25/20.
File three: 7/1/20 entered 8/26/20; 9/30/19 entered 10/8/19.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Renewal evaluation dated 9/11/18, CAP approved 10/2/18
Interim evaluation dated 10/14/19; CAP approved 11/7/19
FOM 722-06B Family team meeting
Page 1-7
Type Time Frame
9

Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 14 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Permanency Goal Review at Six Months in Care Within 30
calendar days from the date the child has been in care for six
months…
Five of eleven FC/IL case records did not have FTMs completed as required.
File one: January, April and July 2020 USPs did not have FTMs completed within 30
days prior to the report approval.
File two: April 2020 USP did not have an FTM completed within 30 days prior to
report approval. In addition, a Semi-Annual Transition Plan FTM was not completed
as required in September 2019 and March 2020.
File three: September 2019 USP did not have an FTM completed within 30 days
prior to report approval.
File four: Semi-Annual Transition Plan FTM report was not completed after the
September 2019 FTM.
File five: Semi-Annual Transition Plan FTM was not held within 30 days of youth’s
14th birthday. Youth’s birthday was 12/4/19 and the FTM occurred on 1/23/20.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Renewal evaluation dated 9/11/18, CAP approved 10/2/18.
Interim evaluation dated 10/14/19; CAP approved 11/7/19
FOM 722-08C Required participation in development of treatment plans
Page 2
The foster parent/caregiver must be included in the PATP
process. The foster parent/caregiver signature is required and
indicates that the foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and
agrees to the activities required to meet the needs of the child in
their care.
Parents and youths age 14 and older must sign the PATP. If a
parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the PATP,
foster care workers must identify and document additional
action needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s participation
in service planning and compliance with the PATP.
CI 17-099
All treatment plans with a report date of August 1, 2017, or later
must have signatures from all appropriate case members within
30 days of the report date.
10

Seven of eleven files did not have Parent/Agency Treatment Plans signatures as
required.
File one: IL youth did not sign November 2019 PATP until September 2020.
File two: November 2019 and April 2020 PATPs are missing foster parent signature.
File three: April 2020 PATP is missing the parent’s signature. February 2020 PATP
is missing the youth’s signature. Additional, PATPs were not signed timely: 12/2/19
plan signed by parent on 1/28/19 and the youth signature was undated; 2/18/20 plan
had an undated parent signature; 5/1/20 plan was signed by youth on 8/18/20.
File four: December 2019 PATP is missing caregiver signature. 9/30/19 PATP was
not signed until 12/12/19.
File five: PATP signature pages were not uploaded and therefore could not be
reviewed for October 2019, January 2020. Two PATPs were signed late: 4/15/20
plan signed 9/8/20 and 6/28/20 plan signed 9/8/20.
File six: January, April and July 2020 PATPs did not have the youth or caregiver’s
signature.
File seven: 7/23/20 PATP did not have the parent or foster parent signature.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Renewal evaluation dated 9/11/18, CAP approved 10/2/18.
Interim evaluation dated 10/14/19; CAP approved 11/7/19
IV. ANALYST INFORMATION
One safety alert was reported by the DCWL analyst. A relative caregiver reported
not receiving a medical authorization card for the child placed in their home. The
case file was reviewed and found no documentation of the card being provided. This
is cited above under policy FOM 801. The agency emailed the relative caregiver a
medical authorization card on 6/17/20. The relative replied to the email, confirming
receipt of the card. A social work contact was entered in MiSACWIS and confirmed
by DCWL on 6/18/20.
V. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Licensing Compliance Record (3080) recommendation should include age,
sex, characteristics of the children that appropriate for placement in the foster
home.
 CI 19-090 was reviewed and the agency understood the need to enter sibling
visits as a separate contact, even if they occur at the same time as parenting
time.
VI. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
11

 The facility’s previous CAP was reviewed. Ongoing consultation was offered
as the new CAP is developed.
12

VII. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
A special evaluation was initiated on 11/9/19. The allegations were that the foster
parents threatened a child in the home, stating that if he told the truth about another
child being thrown down the stairs, he would be in trouble. Additionally, it was
reported a child was AWOL for two days, and encouraged by the foster parent to
stay AWOL to prevent being moved. The special evaluation concluded on 4/20/20
with violations of 9201 Foster Parent qualifications, 9205 Records check, 9207
Subsequent evaluations, with a recommendation of revocation. The revocation is in
process with DCWL.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this 24 month licensing period.
On 8/30/18 a renewal evaluation was completed. The agency was found to be in
violation of 205 required staff, 306 application request, 324 reevaluation, 325 license
recommendation, 413 medical/dental care,417 Foster parent info, 418 Development
of service plans, 420 updated service plans, 502 program statement, 503 policy and
procedures, 504 eligibility requirements, 509 independent living record, 510 IL
contract, ISEP 4.11 MiSACWIS use, 722-9c Foster care action summary, 722-03
Placement selection and standards, 801 Health services for children, 722-9c Foster
parent agency treatment plans, 722-6h caseworker contacts, 722-03b relative
engagement and placement, 722-6b Family team meetings, 801 Medical Passports,
722-6I visitation and contact, 722-7f Permanency planning, 722-3c Older youth
preparation. A CAP was approved on 10/3/18.
On 9/23/2019 an interim evaluation was completed. The agency was found to be in
violation of 312 Foster Parent training, 324 Reevaluations, 327 Special evaluations,
405 change of placement, 413 Medical & dental care, 417 Foster parent information,
418 development of service plans, 502 Program statement, 507 Medical/dental and
mental health for independent living, 504 Eligibility for IL, 505 Supervision for IL, 510
Independent living contract, 509 IL record, 403 FC policy & procedure- visitation,
FOM 722-03 Placement exception request, 801 Medical passports, 722-06B Family
Team Meeting, 722-08C Parent Agency Treatment Plans, and 722-06H Timely Entry
of Caseworker Contacts. A CAP was approved on 11/7/19. Although there were
several repeat violations during the review, the agency also showed improvement in
many areas. In addition to staffing stability, multiple processes and tracking systems
were implemented and assisted in improvements in many areas.
During this review period the agency continues to show progress. In 2018 there
were 28 violations (19 repeats), in 2019 there were 22 violations (11 repeats).
During this review there were 17 violations (14 repeats). While there continues to be
a high number of repeat violations, the instance of each repeat has decreased. The
13

facility’s prior CAPs have shown to be effective, although they need continued
monitoring and adjustment. The agency has expressed a commitment to these
improvements.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
September 10, 2020
